Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Advanced Computational System for Assessing Genetic Provenance in Crop Plants and its Practical Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project will be the development of a highly accurate genotype analysis technique and the computational pipeline for assessing genetic provenance in crop plants. The commercial potential of the proposed products and services is based on the need to increase crop yield and accelerate breeding programs. The proposed technology will revolutionize the field of plant selection by enabling breeders to analyze genotypes of individual plants and optimize crosses. Provided that most of ancestry data on major crops are not publicly available, the platform opens up a range of opportunities for researchers and practitioners. Since it is organism-independent, the software will be applied for analysis of biodiversity and adaptation of species to climate change. These species include, for example, fruit fly, Arabidopsis, Medicago, rat, mouse, as well as endangered plant and animal species such as pandas, bonobos, or whales. Organism-specific pipelines for predicting phenotype using a whole-genome prediction and modeling approach will be established. Free educational versions of the solution will be provided to academic institutions.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop and test a novel software modeling solution that will be the first-in-class commercial "whole genome" tool in the booming agro-genomics segment, designed to deduce the exact percentages of genetic lines that went into given organism solely based on its genotype. This tool will help farmers to effectively select plants with required traits, and also will automatically identify possible genetic contamination that is a common problem in plant species. The solution will be cloud based with a friendly front end enabling breeders and biologists to easily operate and gain insights from complex plant datasets. This visualization tool will be customizable for various species and types of geographical/climate data. Visual integration of geographical, phenotypical, and genomic data will help breeders deducing relationship among individual plants, strains, and variants. The phenotypes will include yield, height, photosynthetic performances, metabolites concentrations, fitness, drought tolerance, cold tolerance, and quantitative disease resistance. The software will be a revolutionary discovery tool enabling agro-companies to significantly reduce number of breeding experiments, and make the breeding process predictable and efficient.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advanced Computational System for Assessing Genetic Provenance in Crop Plants and its Practical Applications

Our project is devoted to developing novel in silico methods of crop selection, a field which is known as “genome selection”. Our approach consists of whole genome sequencing or genotyping of parent plants followed by applying advance math for predicting the plants’ fit with environment and climate and phenotypes of their direct descendants. As a result, we expect substantial progress in breeding of most crops, both in the short term (choosing the best hybrids for planting in current season) and in the long term (optimizing crosses and selection of parent lines). The principal difference between genome selection and other modeling methods applied in crop breeding is reliance not on certain genetic markers but on the “whole genome” landscape of all genetic variants of the plant. Genome selection is a superior method for predicting plant traits with multi-gene inheritance, which constitute the most agriculturally valuable traits in modern crops. In the long run, this method is expected to challenge GMO technology currently prevailing in crop agriculture, particularly in the US.

In Phase I, we have developed several new algorithms for predicting phenotypic traits based on whole-genome genotype and validated them on a model legume Medicago truncatula. Our main technical goal was to generate realistic models for correlating tens of thousands of genetic variants (genotype) with quantitative traits with polygenic inheritance and predict expression of particular traits in a given geography, climate, soil and pest environment. We have successfully completed this goal as follows: 1. developed two novel algorithms for calculating quantitative traits and genetic distance based on global and local (rLAI) phenotypes; 2. validated the algorithms in a collaborative study on the model legume Medicago truncatula. in this study, we predicted both the physical distance between populations and pest resistance;   3. built a prototype software package ProvenancePredictor with interface for data upload, parameters selection and execution of computational algorithms.  The novel algorithms and the software package for breeders are the main outcomes of Phase I. The results of Phase I can be directly applied by breeders with bioinformatics and data mining backgrounds. As the data source, they would need the list of variants of their reference plants or populations in any format (a whole-genome sequence, a GBS (genotyping by sequencing) file or a genotyping microarray readout) and our algorithms could be used within GUI for predicting the best fit in terms of climate, soil and geography. The other important traits, such as yield or pest resistance can be calculated if they upload sufficient data on parent lines (genotypes and phenotypes). Right now, our tools work only on homozygote plants and not suitable yet for predicting phenotypic properties of hybrids (a very important application in crop breeding). We are planning for adding this feature after completing a field study in Phase II.

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2017
Modified by: Yuri Nikolsky

The principal difference between genome selection and other modeling methods applied in crop breeding is reliance not on certain genetic markers but on the "whole genome" landscape of all genetic variants of the plant.
